title: Question 33

children: A 69-year-old man is evaluated in the ICU for the sudden onset of severe, constant periumbilical pain. He was admitted 2 days ago for new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate and heart failure. He reports an urge to defecate but has not had a bowel movement in 2 days. Current medications are metoprolol, furosemide, losartan, and heparin.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 112/min and irregular, and respiration rate is 24/min. The patient appears to have significant pain. Cardiac examination discloses an irregularly irregular rhythm. The abdomen is nondistended and soft, with mild tenderness to deep palpation in the mid abdomen; bowel sounds are present. Rectal examination reveals brown stool.
An abdominopelvic CT scan obtained without intravenous contrast is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next?
Early acute mesenteric ischemia most commonly presents with abrupt onset of severe periumbilical abdominal pain followed by the urge to defecate and an unremarkable abdominal examination.
CT angiography is the recommended imaging modality for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia.
The most appropriate diagnostic test to perform next is CT angiography (

). This patient has acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI) caused by an abrupt decrease in blood flow to the small intestine, likely due to an embolus related to atrial fibrillation. AMI most commonly presents with abrupt onset of severe periumbilical abdominal pain followed by the urge to defecate. Although the patient reports severe abdominal pain, physical examination reveals a soft, nontender, nondistended abdomen without peritoneal signs. Pain that is disproportionate to physical examination findings should immediately raise suspicion for early AMI. With late presentation, intestinal ischemia progresses to infarction and peritoneal signs develop. This late presentation of AMI is associated with a high mortality rate. Results of laboratory studies and abdominal imaging in early AMI are nonspecific. Most patients will have an elevated leukocyte count. Serum lactate level may be normal and does not exclude the diagnosis. CT angiography is the recommended imaging modality to diagnose AMI.

This patient's presentation is not consistent with colonic ischemia, and colonoscopy is not indicated.
